subject: Photography
title: How a Digital Sensor Works
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on How a Digital Sensor Works.

hook.text: A camera sensor is a grid of millions of tiny light collectors. Each one captures a single pixel.

buildup.text: Photons hit the sensor. Each photosite converts light into an electrical charge. More light, more charge.

discovery.text: The charge is measured, converted to a number, and stored. Your photo is literally millions of numbers.

twist.text: Each photosite only sees brightness, not color. Color comes from a tiny filter ‚Äî usually red, green, or blue.

climax.text: Software interpolates the missing colors for each pixel. Your full-color image is a calculated estimate.

punchline.text: A photo is millions of tiny guesses about color.

quiz.question: How do digital sensors detect color?
options: Color filters over each photosite plus software interpolation
Each pixel naturally sees all colors
A prism splits light before the sensor
